Cookbook:Yorkshire Pudding (Vegan).desc: Yorkshire pudding is a dish popular across the UK but originating in the county of Yorkshire in England. It's traditionally eaten with beef or lamb with vegetables.
Cookbook:Yorkshire Pudding (Vegan).Ingredients:
1 cup (240 g) unbleached white flour
1 cup (240 g) whole wheat pastry flour
1 tsp salt
Ener-G egg replacer equivalent of 2 eggs
1 cup (240 ml) soy milk
1 cup (240 ml) very cold water
2 Tbsp vegan margarine, melted
Cookbook:Yorkshire Pudding (Vegan).Procedure:
Preheat the oven to 425degF (210degC).
In a mixing bowl, combine the flours and salt. Make a well in the center and add the egg replacer mixture. Stir together until just combined, then add the soy milk and water, a bit at a time. Stir until smooth, but don't overbeat.
Swirl the melted margarine around a shallow, 9x13-inch (22-32 cm) baking pan. Pour out any excess and reserve. Pour the batter into the pan and pour any remaining margarine over the top.
Bake for 20 minutes, or until golden on top and a knife inserted into the center comes out clean. Let cool, then cut into squares to serve.

Cookbook:Yorkshire Pudding.desc: A Yorkshire pudding is a light, fluffy dish that is usually cooked and served alongside a roast dinner, traditionally made with roast meat--especially roast beef. It comes from Yorkshire, a region in the United Kingdom, and is popular across the island. The exact recipe differs from area to area, even from family to family, so the below recipe offers a generic approach to the tasty pudding.[1]
Cookbook:Yorkshire Pudding.Ingredients:
140 g plain flour
4 ea. (200 g) eggs
200 ml milk
Sunflower oil or meat drippings
 1/4 teaspoon salt
 1/4 teaspoon pepper
Thyme (optional)
Rosemary (optional)
Mustard powder (optional)
Sage (optional)
Red onion (optional)
Cookbook:Yorkshire Pudding.Equipment:
2 x 4-hole Yorkshire pudding tins, or a 12-hole large muffin tin
Large bowl
Jug
Whisk
Sieve
Silicone spatula
Oven gloves
Cookbook:Yorkshire Pudding.Procedure:
Preheat the oven to 230degC (210degC convection)
Fill your tin(s) with a thin layer of your chosen oil, and place into the oven to heat up.
Sieve flour into a bowl, then beat in eggs until smooth.
Slowly add the milk in stages, beating as you go until well-mixed.
Season with salt and pepper. Add optional ingredients as desired.
Transfer the batter to a pouring jug. For best results, rest the batter in the fridge for 1 hour.
Being swift, but careful, remove the hot tin(s) from the oven, and evenly fill the holes with your batter.
Place the tin(s) back into the oven, and leave them undisturbed for 20-25 minutes until puffed and golden brown. Opening the oven door can upset the cooking of the Yorkshire puddings--trust the process and watch with the door closed.
Serve immediately. They can also be cooled and frozen for up to 1 month.
Cookbook:Yorkshire Pudding.Notes, tips, and variations: For the best Yorkshire puddings, make sure your oil is as hot as it can be. Try a little batter first to see if it instantly puffs up.
Cookbook:Yorkshire Pudding.References: | Beeton, Isabella (1907). Mrs. Beeton's Book of Household Management. p. 972.

Cookbook:Yogurt Dip.Ingredients:
2 cups (480 ml) plain yogurt
 1/2 cucumber, seeded and chopped very fine
 1/4 tsp dried mint, crumbled, or 1 tsp fresh, chopped
Cookbook:Yogurt Dip.Procedure: Mix all the ingredients, and chill thoroughly to let the flavors develop.

Cookbook:Yogi Tea.desc: Yogi tea is a spiced tea similar to chai. It is also the brand name of a line of herbal teas.
Cookbook:Yogi Tea.Ingredients:
15 whole cloves
20 black peppercorns
3 sticks of cinnamon
20 green cardamom pods (crushed or split)
8 or more  1/4-inch (0.75cm) slices of fresh ginger root
 1/2 tsp black tea (decaffinated black tea is acceptable)
Cookbook:Yogi Tea.Procedure:
Bring 2 quarts (about 2 L) water to boil in 3-4-quart pot.
Add cloves and boil for 1 minute.
Add peppercorns, cinnamon, cardamom pods and ginger.
Cover and simmer gently for at least 30 minutes. For best flavor, cover tightly and simmer over low heat for 2-3 hours.
Remove from heat and add tea.
Let cool.
Strain ingredients from the finished tea.
When ready to drink, sweeten to taste with honey or maple syrup. Add soy milk or dairy milk.

Cookbook:Yerushalmi Kugel (Sweet Noodle.desc: Yerushalmi kugel is named after the city of Jerusalem. Legend has it that it originated in Jerusalem with the followers of the Vilna Gaon in the 18th century.
Cookbook:Yerushalmi Kugel (Sweet Noodle.Ingredients:
8 oz (200 g) noodles (egg noodles are preferred, but others work fine as well)
 2/3  cup (160 g) sugar (white sugar is helpful because it's more obvious when it begins to brown)
4 tbsp olive oil
1 handful of raisins
1-2 tsp pepper
1 tsp cinnamon
3 eggs
Cookbook:Yerushalmi Kugel (Sweet Noodle.Procedure:
Boil noodles according to the package instructions and drain.
Heat the olive oil in a frying pan, and add  1/3  cup (80 g) sugar.
Stir continuously until the sugar begins to brown. Remove from heat.
The sugar will continue to brown for a few more minutes, creating a thick caramel.
Add the caramel to the noodles.
Add the sugar, eggs, cinnamon, pepper, and raisins. Stir.
Bake in a pan at 350degF (180degC) until the top begins to brown (about 40 minutes).

Cookbook:Yellow Split Pea Soup.Ingredients:
1 pound ( 1/2 kilogram) dry yellow split peas
2 chicken or beef bouillon cubes
1 small onion, chopped
1 medium carrot, diced
1 stalk celery, chopped
6 cups (1 1/2 liters)  water
Salt and pepper to taste
Cookbook:Yellow Split Pea Soup.Procedure:
Soak split peas up to six hours in cold water if you wish. This is not necessary, but will shorten cooking time.
Put all ingredients into a 6 or 8 quart stock pot or Dutch oven
Bring to a boil, then simmer covered until peas are tender, 1-2 hours.
Cookbook:Yellow Split Pea Soup.Notes, tips, and variations:
Watch water level and top up with hot water if necessary.
Croutons are good on top!

Cookbook:Yeasted Rolls II.Ingredients:
1 teaspoon active dry yeast
1 1/4 cups (300 ml) lukewarm milk
1 tablespoon white sugar
3 cups (360 g) unbleached all-purpose flour
 1/4 teaspoon salt
2 tablespoons butter, melted and cooled
Cookbook:Yeasted Rolls II.Procedure:
In a small bowl, dissolve the yeast in the milk and add the sugar.
In another bowl, sift the flour and salt together and add the cooled melted butter.
Add the yeast mixture to the flour mixture, turn out onto a floured counter, and knead until the dough is smooth and elastic.
Place the dough in an oiled bowl, cover with a clean towel and let rise in a warm, draft free place to 45 minutes.
Turn dough out onto the freshly floured board and shape into 9 balls. Place dough balls into a buttered and floured 9-inch square pan. Let them sit, covered, for another 15 minutes to rise again. Preheat the oven to 425degF (220degC).
Bake for 15-20 minutes until browned and puffed. Split open and serve warm.

Cookbook:Yeasted Cornbread.Ingredients:
1 cup warm water
1 tablespoon active dry yeast
4 tablespoons white granulated sugar
1 cup yellow cornmeal
 1/2 cup white flour
 1/2 cup whole wheat flour
1 teaspoon salt
Additional water, as necessary
Cookbook:Yeasted Cornbread.Procedure:
Mix water, yeast, and sugar. Let this sit for a few minutes until it bubbles.
Stir in the rest of the ingredients, adding water until it is pourable.
Bake in a greased 9x9-inch pan at 350degF (175degC, gas mark 4) for 25 minutes or until the edges turn golden brown.

Cookbook:Yam Casserole.Ingredients:
2 cans (2 lb + 8 oz / 900 g) yams or sweet potatoes, drained (or 4 lb / 1.8 kg cooked, peeled, and sliced yams)
 2/3  cup orange juice
1 tablespoon grated orange rind
 1/2 cup bourbon
2 teaspoons salt
1 teaspoon ground ginger
4 tablespoons butter, melted
 1/3  cup packed brown sugar
3 egg yolks
Fresh pepper to taste
Topping
2/3  cup packed brown sugar
 1/4 lb butter, melted
1 cup (about 4 oz / 110 g) pecans, chopped
1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
Cookbook:Yam Casserole.Procedure:
In mixing bowl with electric mixer, beat yams. Add in remaining main ingredients, beating until mixture is light and fluffy. Butter a 12-inch porcelain quiche dish or a shallow 2 quart casserole dish (7x11 inches / 18 x 28 cm). Pour in yam mixture, smoothing top evenly.
Make praline topping by mixing all ingredients together in small bowl. Spread evenly over the yams. May be refrigerated covered overnight.
Bake at 350degF (180degC) for 45-50 minutes or until golden brown and bubbly.
Remove from oven and let stand 10 minutes before serving.
